name: NPR
text:
Inspired by her family, a high school senior has created a tool that predicts crop harvests to help reduce food insecurity.

"I have watched my younger siblings struggle with the lifelong effects of malnutrition," she says.
https://t.co/EZrdNnFUmw

name: NPR
text:
In his plan to address racial inequity, Joe Biden is proposing that the Federal Reserve refocus its attention onto America's significant racial economic gaps — and make sure the Fed regularly talks about those disparities.
https://t.co/5zVzJ2R4l5

name: NPR
text:
Cuba has opened stores for shoppers with U.S. dollars and dropped a tax on dollar transactions.

The government is trying to pull the country out of a deep economic slump — made worse by the pandemic.
https://t.co/yAcrEsSKIe

name: NPR
text:
A collection of Frederick Douglass artifacts will now be available to the public.

It includes letters to his family, his scrapbooks, and drafts of his 1852 speech "What to the Slave is the Fourth of July?" (@hereandnow)
https://t.co/cDPoXFBcrx

name: NPR
text:
"We're talking about a massive problem that has ripple effects, obviously, for the kids, but for society at large," says the study's co-author. "It's effectively limiting the potential of a third of the world's children."
https://t.co/5Fxv7LQT6H

name: NPR
text:
For generations, the Khasi people have been training tree roots to grow together into living, functional bridges that can last for centuries.

And they do it with a tree many of us keep as a common houseplant: Ficus elastica.
https://t.co/dDSFPhnxFv

name: NPR
text:
It can be tough to forgive. But forgiving someone actually has benefits for your own mental health. The practice of radical forgiveness can help you process hurt and anger — and ultimately find peace.

Here are tips to get started. (@nprlifekit)
https://t.co/BjYokmgJkT

name: NPR
text:
Nationwide, Latinx people are hospitalized for COVID-19 at four times the rate of white people.

To help in his community, one pastor is using his Spanish-language radio station to share info about the virus — and how to stay safe.
https://t.co/8RIDvFvx9F

name: NPR
text: Writer/director Amy Seimetz's darkly, darkly comic meditation on the contagious nature of anxiety and paranoia plays with horror conventions while refusing to embrace the genre's pulpy pleasures. https://t.co/wxcxLtdbiI
